sen.j: 永田 徳本（ながた とくほん、1513年（永正10年） - 1630年3月27日（寛永7年2月14日 (旧暦)））は、戦国時代 (日本)後期から江戸時代初期にかけての医師。
sen.e: Tokuhon NAGATA (永田徳本: 1513-March 27, 1630) is a doctor living from the late Sengoku Period (period of warring states) (Japan) to the early Edo Period.
Tokuhon NAGATA (永田徳本: 1513-March 27, 1630) was a doctor living from the late Sengoku Period (period of warring states) to the early Edo Period.
sen.cmt: 「is」→「was」, 「(Japan)」削除 as this is clear from the context, and removing it avoids consecutive parentheses.
sen.e: Tokuhon NAGATA (1513 - March 27, 1630) was a doctor living from the late Sengoku Period (period of warring states) to the early Edo period.

sen.j: 戦国時代中期の1513年、三河国で生まれたという（甲斐国谷村など、異説もある）。
sen.e: It is said that he was born in 1513, the middle of the Sengoku Period in Mikawa Province (among others, according to another theory he was born in Kai Province).

sen.j: その後、陸奥国で仏門に入り、出羽国（鹿島ともいう）で修験道を学び、また田代三喜、玉鼎らより李朱医学（当時の明からもたらされた漢方医学）を修めた、信濃国・甲斐国に移り住み、国主であった戦国大名武田信虎・武田信玄父子二代の侍医となったと言われる。
sen.e: Afterwards, he became a Buddhist monk in Mutsu Province, and in Dewa Province (also said in Kagoshima) he learned Shugendo (mountaineering asceticism). and after learning Ii-Zhu medicine (Chinese medicine brought about at that time from Ming) under Sanki TASHIRO, Otei, and others.

sen.e: Afterwards, he became a Buddhist monk in Mutsu Province, and in Dewa Province (also called Kagoshima) he learned Shugendo (mountain asceticism) and after learned Ii-Zhu medicine (a kind of Chinese medicine brought to Japan during the Ming era) under Sanki TASHIRO, Otei, and others.
sen.cmt: 「said in」→「called」,「mountaineering」→「mountain」, 「.」削除,「learning」→「learned」, 「Chinese medicide brought about at that time from Ming」→「a kind of Chinese medicine brought to Japan during the Ming era」
sen.e: Afterwards, he became a Buddhist monk in Mutsu Province, and in Dewa Province (also called Kashima) he practiced Shugendo (mountain asceticism) and subsequently studied Ii-Zhu medicine (traditional Chinese medicine brought to Japan during the Ming dynasty) under Sanki TASHIRO, Otei, and others.

sen.j: 信濃国・甲斐国に移り住み、国主であった戦国大名武田信虎・武田信玄父子二代の侍医となったと言われる。
sen.e: he moved to Shinano Province and then to Kai Province, where it is said that he served as personal doctor for Nobutora TAKEDA and his son Shingen TAKEDA, who were the provincial lords and daimyo in the Sengoku period.

sen.j: 武田信虎の領国追放後は信濃国諏訪に住み、武田氏滅亡後は東海・関東諸国を巡り、貧しい人々に無料で薬を与えたり、安価で診療を行ったとされる。
sen.e: It is said that after the expulsion of Nobutora TAKEDA from the territory, Tokuhon lived in Suwa, Shinano Province, and after the downfall of the Takeda clan, he traveled around the provinces in Tokai and Kanto districts, offering medicines to poor people with free of charge or providing them medical care at a low price.

sen.j: 伝承に拠れば彼は首から薬袋を提げ、牛の背に横になって諸国を巡り、どんな治療を行っても報酬として16文（18文ともいう）以上の金額を受け取らなかったと伝わり、「十六文先生」とも称されたらしい。
sen.e: According to the traditions, he roamed across the provinces, hanging a medicine bag from his neck and going on the back of a cow, and he dared not to receive more than 16 mon (or 18mon in another theory) for any kind of treatment, and therefore, he was also called 'Juroku (16)-mon doctor.'

According to tradition he roamed across the provinces on a cow, with a medicine bag hanging around his neck, and regardless of the treatment he gave to people he would not to receive more than 16 mon (or 18mon according to other sources), and therefore he began to be called 'Juroku (16)-mon doctor.'

According to legend, Tokuhon roamed around the provinces on a cow, medicine bag dangling from his neck and, regardless of the treatment he provided he refused to take more than 16 mon (mon=old minor unit of currency/penny), or possibly 18 mon (according to some sources), lead him to be referred to as 'Doctor 16 pennies.'

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ったのち、征夷大将軍徳川秀忠の病を治癒し、その際も報酬を受けずに立ち去ったと言われるなど、その人生は謎と伝説に包まれている。
sen.e: It is also said that in the Edo Period, he cured the disease of Seii taishogun (literally, 'great general who subdues the barbarians'), Hidetada TOKUGAWA, but his life is shadowy with mysteries and legends.
